You can create your own style components in addition to build-in styling primitives. Defining your own components gives you greater control over when the content is updated, and allows for cleaner organization of your code.

One of the most important properties of declarative styling is stable content ordering. Essentially, this means that all layers defined in the declarative description will be positioned on the map relative to each other, following a similar pattern as

code: /// The green polygon is displayed on top of the yellow polygon.

The purple circle displayed on top of all content because View Annotations are always rendered on top of the
view.  The yellow polygon is always displayed below the green one, even if the
property was toggled.

to override the positioning. Instead, use new

If there is more than one layer in the slot, they are ordered following the order in the code.

To achieve the best performance, it is recommended to use custom components of
or
to isolate components updates.
This is because whenever you update the
(via
) or
(via SwiftUI

change) internally the full content tree must be compared with its previous version to perform the most efficient update. Having a larger tree of components instead a flat list makes internal caching to be more efficient.
This is very important if you use a large json arrays inside of styling primitives. Lets consider the following example:

code: /// WARNING: This code may be not optimal for large feature collection.
/// Counter updates here will trigger the `body` re-evaluation. This in turn
/// triggers the Map update that need to check if the `features` are changed.
/// This may be a costly operation.

inlineContent.text: This code may not be optimal, because on every
re-evaluation, the large feature set needs to be re-evaluated too.
To optimize it, create a custom component that will consume data by a reference type instead. In the example below, the
will be re-evaluated only when the actual
object is changed. If only the
is updated, the large route JSON won’t be re-evaluated.

code: /// A simple reference wrapper around FeatureCollection.
/// A custom route component that renders the line layer and creates the data source for it.
/// The `body` is called only when component's properties are changed.
/// In this case the `route` is a reference type, which guarantees the fast equality check.
/// Update of the counter state won't trigger the RouteComponent.body evaluation because
/// routeData points to the same data.
/// This will correctly update the rendered route, only once.

The Mapbox Maps SDK v11 introduces improvements to how Mapbox works on iOS platforms, as well as changes to how developers use the SDK. This document summarizes the most important changes - such as new features, deprecated APIs, and breaking changes - and walks you through how to upgrade an application using v10 of the Mapbox Maps SDK to v11.
